para.paratext: The new Evidence Code does not contain the definition of “preponderance of the evidence” from former O.C.G.A. § 24-1-1(5).
However, new O.C.G.A. § 24-14-4 states:

In determining where the preponderance of evidence lies, the jury may consider all the facts and circumstances of the case, the witnesses' manner of testifying, their intelligence, their means and opportunity for knowing the facts to which they testified, the nature of the facts to which they testified, the probability or improbability of their testimony, their interest or want of interest, and their personal credibility so far as the same may legitimately appear from the trial. The jury may also consider the number of the witnesses, though the preponderance is not necessarily with the greater number.

McMillan v. Pennsylvania[1] held that sentencing considerations, such as “visible possession of a firearm,” are proved by a preponderance of the evidence. Subsequently, in Apprendi v. New Jersey,[2] the court held that any fact, other than a prior conviction, that increases the penalty for a crime beyond the statutory maximum must be submitted to a jury and proved beyond a reasonable doubt. Moreover, the voluntariness of a confession must be proved by the state by a preponderance of the evidence for the voluntary incriminating statements to be admitted at trial.[3]

Where a copy of a will is propounded for probate in the absence of an original will, the party tendering the copy has to overcome the rebuttable presumption that the testator intended to revoke the original will by a preponderance of the evidence.[4]

In forfeiture cases, once the state has presented a prima facie case for forfeiture, a claimant asserting that he is an innocent owner of the subject property bears the burden of proving such status by a preponderance of the evidence.[5]

In motions to exclude custodial statements made by defendants, the trial court determines such admissibility under the preponderance of evidence standard considering the totality of the circumstances.[6]
Where similar transaction evidence is introduced against a defendant, the state must prove by a preponderance of the evidence that the defendant committed the prior act.[7]
A defendant claiming insanity has the burden of proving the defense by a preponderance of the evidence.[8]
After the entry of a temporary protective order (TPO), the petitioner must prove the allegations of the petition for a restraining order by a preponderance of the evidence.[9]
The proponent of expert opinion must establish its reliability by a preponderance of the evidence.[10]
A defendant must prove by a preponderance of the evidence that he is entitled to immunity from prosecution.[11]
A plaintiff must establish by a preponderance of the evidence in a medical malpractice suit that the negligence either proximately caused or contributed to cause the plaintiff's harm.[12]
A defendant claiming immunity from prosecution due to self-defense must prove self-defense by a preponderance of the evidence.[13]
McMillan v. Pennsylvania, 477 U.S. 79, 106 S. Ct. 2411, 91 L. Ed. 2d 67 (1986).
Apprendi v. New Jersey, 530 U.S. 466, 120 S. Ct. 2348, 147 L. Ed. 2d 435 (2000).
Johnson v. State, 295 Ga. 421, 761 S.E.2d 13 (2014).
Holiday v. State, 332 Ga. App. 747, 774 S.E.2d 793 (2015).
Pena v. State, 297 Ga. 418, 774 S.E.2d 652 (2015) (defendant argued that the Spanish version of Miranda warnings he was given did not adequately inform him of his constitutional rights).
Arbegast v. State, 332 Ga. App. 414, 773 S.E.2d 283 (2015).
